    Standardise GWAS

    standardise_gwas.Rmd

    Here is a simple example of using the standardise_gwas() function to standardise your GWAS input ready for use with other features in this package.

    library(genepi.utils)

gwas <- data.table::fread(system.file("extdata", "example2_gwas_sumstats.tsv", package="genepi.utils"))

gwas
#>           MARKER   CHR       POS   BETA    SE     P   EAF     A1     A2
#>           <char> <int>     <int>  <num> <num> <num> <num> <char> <char>
#>  1: 10:100000625    10 100000625 -0.037 0.137 0.781 0.710      G      A
#>  2: 10:100000645    10 100000645  0.045 0.173 0.961 0.121      C      A
#>  3: 10:100003242    10 100003242 -0.037 0.134 0.480 0.504      G      T
#>  4: 10:100003785    10 100003785 -0.008 0.137 0.743 0.155      C      T
#>  5: 10:100004360    10 100004360  0.045 0.134 0.961 0.838      A      G
#>  6: 10:100004906    10 100004906 -0.037 0.173 0.781 0.740      A      C
#>  7: 10:100004996    10 100004996 -0.008 0.137 0.743 0.323      A      G
#>  8: 10:100005282    10 100005282 -0.147 0.134 0.781 0.930      T      C
#>  9: 10:100007362    10 100007362  0.045 0.173 0.961 0.816      C      G
#> 10: 10:100008436    10 100008436 -0.008 0.208 0.743 0.946      A      G

    Column mapping

    We provide a number of column mapping options for standard GWAS formats through the ColumnMapping() class. The available formats can be queried like so:

    # column mapping object
map_obj <- ColumnMapping()

# available formats
input_formats(map_obj)
#> [1] "default" "metal"   "ieu_ukb" "ns_map"  "gwama"   "giant"

    Standardise GWAS

    A GWAS can then be standardised like so:

    gwas <- standardise_gwas(gwas, input_format="ns_map", build="GRCh37", populate_rsid=FALSE)[]

gwas
#>                      SNP    CHR        BP     EA     OA   EAF   BETA    SE
#>                   <char> <char>     <int> <char> <char> <num>  <num> <num>
#>  1: 10:100000625[b37]A,G     10 100000625      G      A 0.710 -0.037 0.137
#>  2: 10:100000645[b37]A,C     10 100000645      C      A 0.121  0.045 0.173
#>  3: 10:100003242[b37]T,G     10 100003242      G      T 0.504 -0.037 0.134
#>  4: 10:100003785[b37]T,C     10 100003785      C      T 0.155 -0.008 0.137
#>  5: 10:100004360[b37]G,A     10 100004360      A      G 0.838  0.045 0.134
#>  6: 10:100004906[b37]C,A     10 100004906      A      C 0.740 -0.037 0.173
#>  7: 10:100004996[b37]G,A     10 100004996      A      G 0.323 -0.008 0.137
#>  8: 10:100005282[b37]C,T     10 100005282      T      C 0.930 -0.147 0.134
#>  9: 10:100007362[b37]G,C     10 100007362      C      G 0.816  0.045 0.173
#> 10: 10:100008436[b37]G,A     10 100008436      A      G 0.946 -0.008 0.208
#>         P
#>     <num>
#>  1: 0.781
#>  2: 0.961
#>  3: 0.480
#>  4: 0.743
#>  5: 0.961
#>  6: 0.781
#>  7: 0.743
#>  8: 0.781
#>  9: 0.961
#> 10: 0.743

    Custom mapping

    The provided mapping formats can be inspected with get_map(). The input_format input of standardise_gwas() can either be one of the pre-defined mappings (as shown above), or you can provide your own custom mapping in the form of a named list. In this case the list should contain a minimum of the names SNP, CHR, BP, EA, OA, BETA, SE, P, and EAF.

    map_obj <- ColumnMapping()

standard_mapping <- get_map(map_obj, input_format="ns_map")

standard_mapping
#> $SNP
#> [1] "MARKER"
#> 
#> $CHR
#> [1] "CHR"
#> 
#> $BP
#> [1] "POS"
#> 
#> $EA
#> [1] "A1"
#> 
#> $OA
#> [1] "A2"
#> 
#> $BETA
#> [1] "BETA"
#> 
#> $SE
#> [1] "SE"
#> 
#> $EAF
#> [1] "EAF"
#> 
#> $P
#> [1] "P"
    custom_map <- list(SNP  = "snp_marker", 
                   CHR  = "chrom", 
                   BP   = "position", 
                   EA   = "effect_allele", 
                   OA   = "alt_allele", 
                   BETA = "beta", 
                   SE   = "std_error", 
                   P    = "pval", 
                   EAF  = "frq")

# not run
gwas <- standardise_gwas(gwas, input_format=custom_map, build="GRCh37", populate_rsid=FALSE)[]
